Bayonet Thrust.

In his address, Gunner Depew stat-
ed that, on one occasion, and soon
after he was imprisoned, the German
guards learned that he was an Amer-
ican, and thereupon tauntingly sneer-
ed and said, “You Americans are fine}
neutrals. You are supplying the allies
with munitions of war, and, with pro-
visions and food stuffs. Yes, you Amer-
icans are fine neutrals.” Whereupon
Gunner Depew answered him and said,
“Has America ever refused to sell its
products to Germany? Have you for-

SOLDIER BOVS ARE 10
BE GUESTS 0
THEATER

gotien that the submarine ship
‘Deutchland’ reached American shores ———_
0 occasions and purchased Amer- | :
rang nae Pakase ind Ltrs Te All members of the national army
i B : = “| Who have been certified for service

desired to purchase, and did Americans
refuse to sell to you? Why do you
notsend your merchant vessels to our
shores and you can buy all the prod-
ucts we manufacture the same as the
allies, provided you have the money to
pay for them?” Whereupon one of
the German guards thrust a bayonet
into his arm. The wound he exhibit-
ed. And in addition he received ten
days punishment in the guard house}
and his food consisted of water on-
ly.

runner Depew further narrated in-
cidents of brutality. He said that on
more than one occasion he saw the
German guatds thrust the butt of a gun
into the ribs of prisoners and he could
hear their ribs crash. Many prison-!
ers had ribs broken by the cruelty of |
the guards; also many received bayon- |
et thrusts.

He also stated that very little food
was given, and what was given was)
of the worst quality, and that in the!
winter they suffered intensely from
cold. While the prison camps con
tained stoves, no fuel was furnished |
for heating and there were no beds ont
blankets provided for the prisoners,
and they were compelled to sleep on
boards and keep warm the best way

solutely none, and if any prisoners susg-

from Ogden will be guests of Manager
Harmon Peery, of the Ogden theater,
during the engagement of “The
er,” which commences this afternoon
for the first time. The picture
sidered to be very timely and h:
enthusiastically greeted
the country wherever
shown.

“The Slacker’ is not a war Pee
with the characteristic scenes of bat
tle and hospital. It is rather an ex-
/cellent portrayal of.the fight a young |
man goes through after attempting to
escape service and awakens to the
tremendous realization ofthe impor-|
tance of the service he is called upon
to perform. He admits marrying to
escape the draft but after his wife be-
comes estranged upon learning of his
jact, he is stirred to a sense of duty
‘and regains her love. The picture will
have a three days’ run.

All men who have been certified for
| service therefore have been invited to
attend the show as guests of the man-
| agement.

An Early Showing of New Fall Styles in
Women’s and Misses’

Suits, Coats and
Dresses

There is something new every day and each garment may
be confidently depended upon as a faithful reflection of a
style favored by fashion for the autumn season.
WOLFER’S IS A RELIABLE FASHION GUIDE
This store is in close touch with style developments and 1s
in position to know—it does know, and it will never be
guilty of selfish misinformation to its patrons,

We invite all women who may be interested to visit our shop
frequently. They will find a fascination in the changing display
of new fall outer garments as the season advances

ANGLO-AMERICAN
DAY. OBSERVED

Great Demonstration of War
Aims of America and Eng-
land at Blackpool.

A postcard message
this morning by John J.
Des Moines, Iowa, stating that
Lavina McGriff, mother of B. G
Griff, the former fruit grower of North
was
gust 22.

Mrs. McGriff will be remembered as
a former member of the First M. E.
church of Ogden
———————— 1) ) — —
NEW YORK HONORS

BLACKPOOL, England. Sept. 4.—
This is Anglo-American day at Black-
pool, a great demonstration in which
the war aims of America and Eng- |
land will be re-stated having been or-
ganized by the national war aims com-
mittee, of which Premier Lloyd-
George, former Premier Asquith, Chan-

ener Bonar Law and G. N. Barnes, HER DRAFTED MEN
member of the war cabinet, are of-
ficials.
The mayor and other eivil officers
arranged to meet the guests a. the| NEW YORK, Sept. 4.—New York

Central station and escort them in a
procession through the streets to the
Grand theater. At the theater the
meeting is to be addressed by Dr. Wal-
lace Buttrick of the Rockefeller Insti-
tute for Medical Research and by At-
torney-General Smith.

The following resolution was
pared:

“That this meeting records its in-
flexible determination to continue to a
victorious end the struggle for the
maintenance of those ideals of liberty
which are the common sacred cause of
the allies.”

paid homage to her drafted men today
as 30,000 strong they marched singing
in three parades through the centers
of three of the city’s five boroughs. In
Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx
hundreds of thousands of citizens
thronged the lines of march and
cheered them on their way into the
national army as enthusiastically and
affectionately as last week they gave
former national guardsmen God speed
Into federal service at their Spartan-
burg, S. C., camp.

The little men with Singer’s Midgets, the greatest attraction ever presented on a vaudeville stage

There are 30 of these tiny people and they do ten acts of vaudeville. They carry two baby eie-
phants and twenty tiny ponies. This big show on the Pantages bill will play the Orpheum Theater
four days this week opening tomorrow, Wednesday afternoon, playing three shows daily. Spe
cial matinee every day for the children.
